choices.text: Ultrasound guided CT. should be performed in this case

questions.text: A 20-year-old female arrived at the emergency room with a heart rate of 110bpm and blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, respectively. The abdomen was silent and rigid when examined. Which of the following statements about this patient's care is accurate
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute perforation peritonitis.
Among the given options, the correct statement will be option-B. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, she should be subjected to CECT abdomen which will help in localizing the site of perforation and it's likely etiology.
The definitive management is to perform exploratory laparotomy after initial fluid resuscitation.
Other options- 
  • x ray is the first investigation which shows free air under diaphragm
  • USG is generally not done
  • Nacrotics may be used for pain relief

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1141.

questions.text: All among the following conditions require ERCP as an indication except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Acute pancreatitis without Choledocholithiasis

ERCP is endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.
It is an invasive procedure helps in diagnosis and management of Biliary- pancreatic duct system. 

Among the given options, ERCP will be least useful in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis. 

The common indications for ECRP are as follows-
  • Recurrent pancreatitis
  • Unexplained Jaundice
  • Periampullary mass
  • Biliary stenting for strictures or leakage
  • Sphincterotomy 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1199.

questions.text: Identity the injury which cannot be diagnosed on eFAST:
questions.solution:
eFAST has poor sensitivity in visualization of retroperitoneal structures.
Therefore, the answer among the given options will be retroperitoneal hematoma. USG cannot visualize structures of retroperitoneum. 
The investigation of choice for retroperitoneal injury is CECT which can be performed only in a hemodynamically stable patient unlike eFAST.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: Full form of FAST is:
questions.solution:
Full form of FAST is focused assessment by sonogram in trauma.

The Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) is an ultrasound protocol developed to assess for hemoperitoneum and hemopericardium.

The sequence of performing eFAST is as follows-
  • Subxiphoid transverse view to look for any pericardial effusion.
  • Right upper quadrant- To look for any liver parenchymal injury, renal laceration or fluid in Morisson's pouch. 
  • Left upper quadrant- To look for any splenic or left renal injury. 
  • Suprapubic region- To look for any fluid in Pouch of Doughlas. 
  • Apart from these, left and right hemothorax for hemothorax and pneumothorax. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: From the options given below, identify the one which is not a feature of the MELD score:
questions.solution:
Albumin among the following is not a component of MELD score.

MELD stands for model for end stage liver disease. MELD score is calculated using serum bilirubin, serum creatinine, and International normalised ratio (INR).

COMPONENTS OF MELD SCORE: [Mnemonic- C.B.I]
  1. Creatinine
  2. Bilirubin and
  3. INR (PT)
It may also include Sodium levels which is known as MELD-Na score.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2635, 2636.

questions.text: Dextrose 100g, amino acids 30g, and lipids 40g are all included in a TPN bag. What are the calories provided
questions.solution:
Provided calories are 880. 1 gm of dextrose provides 4 kcal of energy, amino acid provides 4 kcal of energy and 1 gm of lipid provides 9 kcal of energy. Therefore, 100g of dextrose contains 100*4=400 Kcal 30g amino acid contains 30*4=120 Kcal 40g lipids contain 40*9=360 Kcal Total calories come out to be 880.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 468

choices.text: Mattox manoeuvre involves left medial visceral rotation(descending colon/splenic flexure) to expose the aorta.
Pelvic trauma should always be surgically explored.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about retroperitoneal hematoma is true?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is Option B- Mattox manoeuvre which involves left medial visceral rotation, that is, medialisation of splenic flexure and descending colon to expose the aorta.
  • Cattell-Brasch manoeuvre is right medial visceral rotation to expose the IVC.
  • This exploration is commonly used in abdominal trauma and injuries to zone I or II with hemodynamic instability.

Other options

Option 1 - Zone 3 hematoma(pelvic) are explored only if hematoma is pulsatile or expanding. (or if trauma is penetrating)
Option 3 - Zone 1(midline) injures are near major vessels - hence, should always be explored irrespective if trauma is blunt/penetrating.
Option 4 - Pelvic trauma is zone 3 trauma - hence needs surgical exploration only if hematoma is pulsatile or expanding(or if trauma is penetrating), not always. 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: Identify the appropriate mesh used in Hernia surgery:
questions.solution:
Most appropriate mesh used in hernia surgery is light weight and with large pores.

The light weight mesh have the benefit of lower postoperative pain and lower inflammation as compared to other types.
Large pores are important because they allow for better tissue integration and reduced risk of infection. Larger pores also enable better fluid drainage, which helps to avoid complications such as seroma or abscess formation


Fig: Lichtenstein’s repair


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1068.

questions.text: A stove explosion resulted in the burning of a 23-year-old man. On his face and neck, B/L arms, both upper chest and back. there is hair-singeing. Blisters and peeling were also observed. What is the percentage of burns?
questions.solution:
Percentage of burned area is 45%
In adults, % of burned area is calculated using Wallace’s rule of 9. 
Face and neck=9%
Chest=9%
Upper Back =9%
Each arm=9%  (hence, both arms = 18%)
Total area= 9+9+9+18 =45%









Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: After being received with blood transfusion for a few hours, a 26-year-old male patient who had an accident complicated by a pelvic fracture is febrile, hypotensive, and oliguric. What is the cause of bleeding from the NG tube and IV cannula sites
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is transfusion reaction.
The most common signs and symptoms of transfusion reaction include fever, chills, urticaria (hives) and itching.
Some symptoms resolve with little or no treatment. However, symptoms like respiratory distress, high fever, hypotension (low blood pressure), and red urine (hemoglobinuria) can indicate a more serious reaction.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Tamoxifen used to treat breast cancer won't help in preventing:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial Carcinoma
 
  • Tamoxifen given for Breast cancer will not prevent endometrial carcinoma.
  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used for the treatment and prevention of estrogen receptor (ER) positive breast cancer.
  • Tamoxifen characteristically causes cystic endometrial hyperplasia due to its agonistic action on endometrium, thereby increasing the risk of endometrial cancer (EC) by about 2–7 fold.
  • More aggressive types of EC with poor prognoses are observed in tamoxifen users.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 941.

questions.text: The nerve that will sustain the least damage during thyroid surgery is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Marginal mandibular

Among the given options, marginal mandibular nerve is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery as it is situated higher up among the given nerves. Therefore, it is least likely to be encountered in dissection involved in thyroid surgery. Note- The most common nerve injured in thyroid surgery is ELN ( not RLN ).

The fascia above the facial vessels is palpated in the midportion of the body of the mandible. The nerve is usually identified in the fascia above the vessels and is dissected along its path horizontally to expose it as it exits the parotid and traverses onto the muscles anteriorly.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 843.

questions.text: Upon awakening following parotid surgery, a patient noticed paralysis of the lower lip. Which of the following has sustained the most damage?
questions.solution:
The more appropriate answer to the given Q will be cervical branch of facial nerve which provides some collateral innervation to muscles of lower lip. 

Injury to main trunk of facial nerve wont present with isolated paralysis of lower lip. 

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: A 40 year patient presented with recurrent abdominal pain post cholecystectomy. On USG examination, no significant findings were present. He was discovered to have biliary dyskinesia after additional evaluation by other investigations. Which among the following investigations would not be helpful for diagnosing biliary dyskinesia
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. USG
 
  • Among given options, USG is not done for the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia as the findings are seen to be normal.
  • The diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia can be made by a HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) and ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography). Also post surgery follow up will help in identifying these patients as they will present with persistent right upper quadrant pain after cholecystectomy.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1503.

choices.text: Initial IV access of choice is central venous catheter

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who has had a stomach ache for six hours, now has blood pressure readings of 90/50 mmHg, 24 cycles per minute respiratory rate rate, and oxygen saturation of 92%. Extraluminal air is visible in the abdomen on an abdominal X-ray. Which of the following tasks is required when moving to OT
questions.solution:
Option D- Infusion of 2 to 3 liters of crystalloids must be done before shifting this patient to OT.
The features given are suggestive that the case is of perforation and for that usually we do fluid resuscitation before definitive surgery and Crystalloid fluids are the first choice for fluid resuscitation in maximum cases.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671.

choices.text: APC, Kras and loss of 10 on nyc

questions.text: A colon cancer diagnosis has been made for a male patient. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely to exist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) APC, Kras, P53

In this patient APC, Kras, P53 gene mutations are likely to be present.

* [Extra Edge]: Adenoma-carcinoma sequence:
Fearon and Vogelstein proposed this classic model for the multistage progression of colorectal cancer.
  • A mutation in the APC tumor suppressor gene is generally considered to be the initiation event.
  • This is followed by the sequential accumulation of other epigenetic and genetic changes that eventually result in the progression from a normal cell to a metastatic tumor.
  • The classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence accounts for up to 80% of sporadic cancers and typically includes mutation of APC early in the neoplastic process.
  • Sequence of genetic mutations is in this order APC -> Kras -> P53
  • With loss of APC function, β-catenin accumulates and translocates to the nucleus, where it forms a complex with the DNA-binding factor TCF and activates the transcription of genes, including MYC and cyclin D1, that promote proliferation.
Memorizing Trick: -
AK53- APC, KRAS, P53

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text: In a single-core prostate needle biopsy, poorly formed glands arranged in cribriform pattern is seen. What will be the Gleason pattern in this patient?
questions.solution:
Gleason Pattern-

Pattern 1 and 2- Not defined according to modified Gleason

Pattern 3- Well formed glands

Pattern 4- Cribriform glands/glomeruloid glands/poorly formed

Pattern 5- Comedo-necrosis, individual cells or tumor sheets



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1534.

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium results primarily from:
questions.solution:
Gibbs-donnan equilibrium is mainly contributed by proteins. The Gibbs–Donnan effect describes the behavior of charged particles across a semipermeable membrane. Because some particles cannot diffuse across the membrane (e.g. proteins), their electrostatic presence will result in the asymmetric distribution of permeable ions.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 9

questions.text: From the information below, calculate the ECF volume. 10gm of mannitol was injected into the vein. At equilibrium, plasma mannitol content is 65 mg/100 ml, and urinary excretion is 10%.
questions.solution:
ECF volume will be 14 L

V=(Q-e)/C
  =9000/0.65
  =13.8 Liters

Where Q is the amount of dye injected, e is the excretion rate and C is the final plasma concentration. 

 

Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 13th Edition Page no 309,310

questions.text: Which among the following hormones has intracellular receptor?
questions.solution:
Thyroxin among the following options has intracellular receptors.

Following are the hormones that use intracellular receptors:
  • Thyroxin
  • Aldosterone
  • Steroid hormones
1. Nuclear receptors- Sex hormones, Thyroxine
2. Cell membrane receptors- GPCR or Tyrosine Kinase receptors 
  •  Tyrosine Kinase - Remember PIG - Prolactin, Insulin, GH
  • GPCR - remaining vast majority of hormones (Non PIG)

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 291

choices.text: No such infinite feedback gain is not possible

questions.text: Which among the following feedback systems has infinite gain?
questions.solution:
In case of blood volume control by kidney, the feedback gain is infinity.

Gain is defined as correction/error. When error is 0, gain becomes infinite which is seen with blood volume correction by kidney

The return of arterial pressure always back to the equilibrium point is due to the infinite feedback gain principle for control of arterial pressure by the renal-body fluid mechanism.

 

Reference-:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no:8

questions.text: DHPR and RyR receptors are linked in skeletal muscle by:
questions.solution:
In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR) and ryanodine receptors (RyR) are linked mechanically. This coupling occurs through a physical interaction between the two types of receptors, allowing DHPR, which senses the voltage change, to trigger the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via RyR.

So, the correct answer is 2. Mechanically.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 102,103

questions.text: When a 65-year-old man with chest pain went to the emergency room, his blood pressure was tested as SBP 190 mm Hg and DBP 100 mm Hg. 90 mm Hg is the pulse pressure. For this high pulse pressure, which of the following parameters needs to be reduced
questions.solution:
Arterial wall compliance among the following parameter should decrease for this high blood pressure. Aorta and large arteries act as Windkessel vessels. Low compliance leads to increase in SBP(systolic blood pressure) and decrease in DBP, leading to rise in PP(pulse pressure).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 567,568

choices.text: Volume of serum in the kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following does not have to be considered while determining creatine clearance?
questions.solution:
Volume of serum in kidney in 24 hours is not required for calculation of creatine clearance.
 
  • This clearance estimation based on UV/P formula
  • 24 hour urine is collected and then further creatinine concentration is measured.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: Identify the neuron that receives 500 inputs from 150 different sensory cells:
questions.solution:
Single neuron receive 500 inputs from 150 different sensory cells. It is an example of convergence. Convergence allows a neuron to receive input from many neurons in a network.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8916593/

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical stimulation (TENS) for the treatment of pain involves:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Transcutaneous electrical stimulation TENS for pain management is gating at spinal cord.

Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to treat pain because it modulates and controls the pain signal. A(alpha) and A(beta) fibres close to the injury are activated using electrodes in this technique.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 169

questions.text: Who recorded the first human EEG, the examiner questioned the student during the physiology viva. I'm not sure, the pupil said in response. Examiner decided to offer him a hint since he felt awful, saying that "the name rhymes with what you get at McDonald's". The kid then responded correctly. Which kind of memory does the learner use here?
questions.solution:
The learner in this scenario is using priming. Priming is a type of implicit memory that facilitates the retrieval of information through cues or hints. In this case, the hint about the name rhyming with something associated with McDonald's helped the student recall the name of the person who recorded the first human EEG, which is Hans Berger.

So, the correct answer is 1. Priming.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 279

questions.text: The graph below depicts how quickly different haemoglobin chains normally synthesise both during pregnancy and after birth. Which of the following describes the gamma chain of haemoglobin
questions.solution:
Gamma chain of haemoglobin is indicated by graph B. The foetal Hb is composed of 2 alpha and 2 gamma chains which is changed to the HbA as seen in adults which contain 2 alpha and 2 beta chains. In graph, A- alpha chain, B- gamma chain and C- beta chain

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 632,605

choices.text: Presence of acidophilic serous acini at the tip
Serous acini supported by the basal lamina

questions.text: The exocrine pancreas and parotid differ with respect to:
questions.solution:
Difference between exocrine pancreas and Parotid is the absence of striated duct.

The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has ONLY the intercalated type.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 659, 660

questions.text: Which area of the internal capsule is injured when there is C/L hemiplegia?
questions.solution:
Injury to posterior limb of internal capsule causes C/L hemiplegia.

This is because corticospinal fibers (pyramidal fibers) for upper limb , trunk and lower limb pass through posterior limb of the internal capsule.

Other options:- 
  • genu- contains corticonuclear tract- C/L upper motor neuron lesion of cranial nerves 
  • retro-lentiform- contains optic radiation 
  • sub-lentiform- contains auditory radiation
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 538

questions.text: Which of the following is not a carotid sheath's content
questions.solution:
Sympathetic chain is not a content of carotid sheath. Contents of carotid sheath are: Internal jugular vein Common carotid artery (in the lower part) and internal carotid artery (in the upper part) Vagus nerve in between them



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no. 577,578

questions.text: The superior cerebellar peduncle's decussation level is at:
The medial lemniscus is made up of:
questions.solution:
Medial lemniscus is formed from Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus.

Medial lemniscus is nothing but a continuation of posterior column tract which is formed from
 
  • Fasciculus Gracilis
  • Fasciculus Cuneatus

questions.text: Gastric pit isthmus lining cells are known as:
questions.solution:
Cells lining in the isthmus of gastric pits are stem cells.

The stomach can be divided into two anatomical regions, the corpus (left) and the antrum (right). Both contain stem cell populations, located in the isthmus and the base.

questions.text: Ito cells are found in the liver in:
questions.solution:
Ito cells in liver are present in interstitial space of disse. Stellate cells, also called Ito cells or lipocytes contain lipids and are involved in vitamin A metabolism.

questions.text: Find the pyriform fossa in the illustration:

B is the pyriform fossa.

questions.text: The deep cervical fascia's pretracheal layer encloses everything except:
questions.solution:
Pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all except sternocleidomastoid.

Sternocleidomastoid is enclosed by investing layer of deep cervical fascia. 

The anterior visceral space, also known as the pretracheal space in surgery and radiology, is enclosed by the visceral division of the middle layer of the deep cervical fascia. The trachea, thyroid, parathyroid, larynx, cervical oesophagus, recurrent laryngeal nerves, and cranial sympathetic trunks are all located within it.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 578

questions.text: Select the option that does not contain transitional epithelium:
questions.solution:
Transitional epithelium is present in all except membranous urethra. Membranous urethra is lined by stratified columnar epithelium.

Urinary system upto the prostatic urethra is lined by transitional epithelium.

questions.text: Identify the artery present in close proximity to the highlighted area:

Artery present in close proximity to the marked area is middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient has both hypertension and diabetes mellitus. He presents with late-stage chronic kidney disease. Which anti-diabetic medication of the following needs the least dose adjustment in renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Linagliptin
 
  • Linagliptin is an anti-diabetic drug that requires least dose modification in case of renal disease.
  • Linagliptin is one of the DPP-4 inhibitor drugs
* Other DPP-4 inhibitors used as anti-diabetic are:
  • Sitagliptin
  • Vildagliptin
  • Saxagliptin
  • Alogliptin
All DPP-4 inhibitors require dose adjustment in renal failure except Linagliptin since it has hepatic excretion. 

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1039.

questions.text: Identify the drug responsible for the side effect in the given picture:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Bleomycin
 
  • The side effect given in picture is caused due to bleomycin.
  • The side effect that is shown in the image is FLAGELLATED DERMATITIS and it is caused due to consumption of bleomycin.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1370.

questions.text: An individual was receiving metoprolol treatment for hypertension. VERAPAMIL was also given to him. With the aforementioned combo therapy, which of the following is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

choices.text: it increases the half-life of the drug
It protects the acid labile drug from gastric pH
It increases the absorption of drugs that are preferentially absorbed distal to the stomach
It protects the stomach from irritant drugs

questions.text: Identify the one which is not an advantage of an enteric-coated tablet:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) it increases the half-life of the drug

All of the following are advantages of enteric coated tablet except option A- it increases the half life of the drug.

Certain drugs are degraded in the gastrointestinal tract, e.g. penicillin G by acid, insulin by peptidases, and are ineffective orally.
Enteric coated tablets (having acid resistant coating) and sustained release preparations (drug particles coated with slowly dissolving material) can be used with superadded benefits.

* Advantages of enteric coated tablets are as follows:
 
  • Enteric-coated capsules do not dissolve in the mouth and therefore are perfect for formulations that need not to be activated by acid exposure.
  • This enteric coated capsule typically takes an hour or two to dissolve, making it ideal for time- sensitive medications.
  • It protects the acid labile drug from gastric pH.
  • It protects the stomach from irritant drugs 
  • It increases the absorption of drugs that are preferentially absorbed distal to the stomach
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: Which of the following negative effects is most likely to be brought on by a psychotropic medicine that prevents the reuptake of serotonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sexual Dysfunction 
 
  • A psychotropic drug inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin is likely to cause sexual dysfunction.
  • Due to anticholinergic activity, several SSRIs are known to cause dry mouth and impaired vision.
  • The cause of sexual dysfunction and diarrhea is an increase in serotonin brought by reuptake inhibition.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd line anti-tubercular drug.

Among the following ethionamide is the 2nd line anti-tubercular drug.

streptomycin was previously used as a first-line anti-tubercular drug but now is not used due to it's ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A female patient receiving tamoxifen therapy has unilateral breast cancer. Which of the following negative effects is connected to tamoxifen use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial carcinoma

Endometrial carcinoma is the adverse effect associated with the use of tamoxifen.

* Following are the side effects of tamoxifen:
  • Selective estrogen activation effect (due to which blood clots, stroke and endometrial cancer is seen)
  • Increased tumor or bone pain
  • Hot flashes
  • Mood swings and depression
  • Hair thinning
  • Constipation
  • Loss of libido
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 377.

choices.text: Inhibit implantation by bringing change in the uterus

questions.text: With the exception of ________ combined oral contraceptives work by all of the following mechanisms.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Increase gonadotrophin secretion

Combined oral contraceptive pills act by all of the following mechanics except by increase in gonadotrophin secretion.

* For the combined oral contraceptives, main mechanism of action are as follows-
  • Inhibition of follicular development,
  • Inhibition of ovulation, and as consequence, corpus luteum formation.
  • It is also involved in the alteration of the cervical mucus that inhibit sperm penetration.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 346.

questions.text: Which of the following medications should a patient taking rosuvastatin therapy avoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Clarithromycin

Clarithromycin should be avoided in a patient on rosuvastatin therapy.
  • Inhibition of OATP1B1 by Clarithromycin reduces tissue uptake of rosuvastatin.
  • The overall result is an increase in systemic plasma levels of rosuvastatin, which may result in increased susceptibility to statin-induced myopathy.
  • Efficacy will depend upon the net effect on hepatic levels of rosuvastatin, driven by the lower hepatic uptake via OATP1B1 inhibition.
* All statins, except rosuvastatin are metabolized primarily by CYP3A4.
* Metabolism of Rosuvastatin is mainly done through BCRP and OATP1B1.

Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known role in inducing or inhibiting Rosuvastatin metabolism.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: All of the following medications are bactericidal for Mycobacterium, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Thioacetazone
 
  • Thioacetazone is a thiosemicarbazone prodrug with antitubercular activity. Although the exact mechanism by which thioacetazone exerts its effect has yet to be fully elucidated, this agent, upon activation by bacterial monooxygenase EtaA, appears to target and inhibit cyclopropane mycolic acid synthases (CMASs), a family of S-adenosyl-methionine-dependent methyl transferases responsible for cyclopropanation of mycolic acid.
  • By inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis, the bacterial cell wall becomes more permeable and less resistant to injury which eventually leads to cell lysis.
  • Mycolic acids, long-chain fatty acids, are essential mycobacterial cell wall components and play a key role in resistance to cell injury and mycobacterial virulence.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1267.

questions.text: A patient is receiving ongoing anticonvulsant treatment. The visual field is gradually contracting. The following anti-epileptic drug is most likely to blame for the side effect:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vigabatrin

The likely anti-epileptic drug responsible for the adverse effect is vigabatrin.
A common side effect in case of vigabatrin consumption is the involvement of optic nerve that may lead to progressive contractility of visual field.
* Visual field changes as a rare ocular side effect is seen in case of:
  • Vigabatrin
  • Chloroquine (paracentral scotoma is seen)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 448.

questions.text: Identify the drug that acts through intracellular receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thyroxin

Only Thyroxine acts through intracellular receptors all other act via cell membrane receptors.

* [Extra Edge]:
  • Both T 3 and T4 penetrate cells by active transport and produce majority of their actions by combining with a nuclear thyroid hormone receptor (TR) which belongs to the steroid and retinoid superfamily of intracellular receptors.
  • Two TR isoform families (TRα and TRβ) have been identified. Both bind T 3 and function in similar manner, but their tissue distribution differs, which may account for quantitative differences in the sensitivity of different tissues to T3.
  • In contrast to the steroid receptor, the TR resides in the nucleus even in the unliganded inactive state. It is bound to the ‘thyroid hormone response element’ (TRE) in the enhancer region of the target genes along with corepressors

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 363.

questions.text:
While obtaining a blood sample from a patient who had HIV +ve symptoms, a resident doctor had a needle prick injury. Which of the following regimens is the most effective for this doctor's post-exposure HIV prophylaxis?
1. Zidovudine + Lamivudine
2. Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
3. Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
4. Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Nevirapine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

PEP acc. 2021 guidelines (NACO) is TLD (Tenofovir, Lamivudine and Dolutegravir).
Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Indinavir is the best regimen for post exposure prophylaxis is HIV.

PEP (Post-Exposure Prophylaxis) means taking medicine to prevent HIV after a possible exposure. PEP should be used only in emergency situations and must be started ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours after a recent possible exposure to HIV.

It is taken daily for 28 days/4 weeks. 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1594.

questions.text: Identify the best drug for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cladribine
 
  • DOC for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia is Cladribine.
  • Both pentostatin and cladribine can be used for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia, but cladribine is the drug of choice.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1362.

questions.text: Identify the drug that can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Epsilon amino caproic acid

Epsilon amino caproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose. 

* Mechanism of action- Being a lysine analogue, it combines with the lysin binding site of plasminogen and plasmin. As a result, plasmin is unable to bind to fibrinogen and lyse it. 

* Indication-
  • It is a specific antidote for fibrinolytic agents and has been used in many hyperplasminemic states associated with excessive intravascular fibrinolysis resulting in bleeding.
  • The primary indication of EACA is to counteract the effect of fibrinolytic drugs and bleeding due to their use.
  • In hemophiliacs, it has adjunctive value for controlling bleeding due to tooth extraction, prostatectomy, trauma, etc.
Following are the antidotes that are used in case of fibrinolytic agent overdose
  • Epsilon amino caproic acid
  • Tranexamic acid
Option 1 Ethamsylate reduces capillary bleeding when platelets are adequate; probably corrects abnormalities of platelet adhesion but does not stabilize fibrin (not an antifibrinolytic).

Option 2 Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) Produced by recombinant DNA technology from human tissue culture, it catalyzes the cleavage of endogenous plasminogen to generate plasmin, and is moderately specific for fibrin bound plasminogen, so that circulating fibrinogen is lowered only by ~ 50%.

Option 3 Recombinant coagulation factor Xa, also called Andexanet alfa, is FDA-approved for reversal of patients treated with rivaroxaban and apixaban with serious bleeding.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Which among the following occurs due to stimulation of muscarinic receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Erection

Erection among following is an action expected of muscarinic receptors.
Remaining options occur in response to stimulation of sympathetic nervous system or antagonism of Muscarinic receptors. 

Note- In penis, ejaculation is a sympathomimetic action mediated via alpha 1 receptor whereas erection is a parasympathomimetic action mediated via M3 muscarinic receptors.  

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 113.

questions.text: Identify the drug that is not indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Streptokinase 

All of the following drugs are indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI except streptokinase.
Following are the drugs indicated for the treat of NSTEMI:
 
  • NSTEMI is treated with beta-blockers and statins that improve circulation and prevent further damage to the heart muscle.
  • At the same time, blood thinners like aspirin or Plavix (clopidogrel) are used to prevent blood clots and the complete blockage of the vessel.
  • Patients of NSTEMI who are managed without PCI/thrombolysis are generally put on a combination of aspirin + clopidogrel or ticagrelor, which is continued for upto one year.
Remember- Thrombolysis is not indicated in NSTEMI since the risk of thrombolysis, particularly bleed outweighs its benefit of thrombolysing the clot since the clot in NSTEMI is small in dimension. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 674.

questions.text: Identify the one that is not a prodrug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Primidone

Primidone among following is not a prodrug.

Primidone acts both directly and through its metabolites
This means that Primidone itself is active and also produce active metabolites.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who had Grave's disease was pregnant and receiving medication for hyperthyroidism. She gave birth to a child who has congenital anomaly aplasia cutis congenita. Which medication is most likely to be responsible for this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Carbimazole
 
  • Most likely drug implicated for this teratogenic effect is carbimazole.
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) following is seen following utero exposure to antithyroid drugs such as methimazole or carbimazole. 
  • Aplasia cutis congenita (ACC) or aplasia cutis is a rare skin defect characterized by either a focal or extensive absence of the epidermis, dermis, and in some cases the subcutaneous tissue.
  • It may be unifocal or multifocal and involve underlying bone, intracranial, or vascular structures. Although ACC may affect any part of the body, the scalp is most commonly affected.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 952.
Online Reference: P. Bowman, N.J. Osborne, R. Sturley, B. Vaidya, Carbimazole embryopathy: implications for the choice of antithyroid drugs in pregnancy, QJM: An International Journal of Medicine, Volume 105, Issue 2, February 2012, Pages 189–193, https://doi.org/10.1093/qjmed/hcq248

questions.text: Lithium carbonate was initiated as a treatment for bipolar disorder in a 30-year-old patient. On the side effects of the therapy, the nurse provided instructions. Identify the symptoms upon which the patient must report back.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Tinnitus, severe diarrhea, ataxia
 
  • The patient should report back if the following features are seen- tinnitus, severe diarrhea, and ataxia.
  • Various CNS and GI manifestations are early indications of lithium toxicity.
  • GI manifestations: Diarrhea and vomiting.
  • CNS manifestations: Coarse tremors, drowsiness, muscle weakness, ataxia, blurred vision, and tinnitus.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium

questions.text: When is the monitoring of lithium estimation done for the plasma level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 12 hours after the last dose
 
  • Lithium's effectiveness is dose-dependent and consistently correlated with serum lithium levels (trough levels).
  • The optimum time to measure trough levels is right before the next dose.
  • Lithium is given in two divided doses in clinical practice, trough levels are best assessed 12 hours following the last dosage.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: The activity of vitamin K is countered by dicumarol by:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) Competitive Inhibition.

Dicumarol is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase; thus, it inhibits vitamin K recycling and causes depletion of active vitamin K in blood.

*Mechanism of action:

Dicumarol inhibits the enzyme vit K epoxide reductase (VKOR) and interfere with regeneration of the active hydroquinone form of vit K which acts as a cofactor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase that carries out the final step of γ carboxylating glutamate residues of prothrombin and factors VII, IX and X. This carboxylation is essential for the ability of the clotting factors to bind Ca2+ and to get bound to phospholipid surfaces, necessary for the coagulation sequence to proceed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 667.

questions.text: Identify the one not used in the treatment of polycystic ovarian disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ulipristal 

Ulipristal among the following is not used in treatment of polycystic ovarian disease.

  • birth control pills to regularize periods
  • medication called metformin to prevent diabetes
  • statins to control high cholesterol
  • hormones to increase fertility like - letrozole and clomiphene 
  • procedures to remove excess hair
Ulipristal which is a contraceptive is therefore not used.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 978.

questions.text: Neonatal seizures can be induced by which vitamin deficiency:
questions.solution:
Vitamin deficiency causing neonatal seizure is Pyridoxine.
  • Glutamate is an excitatory neurotransmitter increases the chances of seizure.
  • It is metabolized into GABA, which is inhibitory for the seizure by an enzyme called GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase)
  • Vitamin B6 or pyridoxine is a coenzyme for GAD.
  • Therefore deficiency of pyridoxine can lead to accumulation of glutamate, which causes neonatal seizure.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 118,119,553

questions.text: VSD is corrected to prevent which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correction of VSD is done to avoid or correct failure to thrive.

  • Age 6-12 months with large VSD and pulmonary hypertension
  • Age > 24 months with Qp:Qs ratio > 2:1
  • Supracristal VSD of any size secondary to risk of developing AV insufficiency.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect criteria for defining a case of Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM):
questions.solution:
Weight for age less than 2SD (option 1) is not used to define Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM). 

World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF define severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children 6 to 59 months of age as any one or more  of the following:

1. A weight-to-height ratio that is under three standard deviations (SD or Z scores) from the average WHO growth reference.
2. Bipedal edema is present, or
3. The upper-middle arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm(or 115 mm).


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 336

2. Reversible photo-isomerization

questions.text: Phosphate in urine in excess leads to osteomalacia. Lab findings include low serum phosphate levels, Normal PTH and Normal Vitamin D level. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis most likely associated with excess phosphate in urine leading to osteomalacia is Vitamin D resistance.
  • This condition, also known as hereditary vitamin D-resistant rickets (HVDRR), leads to problems with phosphate and calcium metabolism, contributing to weakened bones and osteomalacia despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D.

Laboratory findings of Vitamin D-resistant rickets:
  • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hyperphosphaturia
  • Normal or mild decreased 1, 25 (OH) D3
  • Normal PTH level

questions.text: A male patient with a history of feverish joints and back discomfort experiences hyperpigmentation across the nose.  He then takes NSAIDs for relief of pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Chikungunya.
  • Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish hyperpigmentation over the nose, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable.
  • This is also known as thr Chik sign
  • This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.(option 3)
  • In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (2) is incorrect)
Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010.

questions.text: When exposed to friction, a male infant born to a non-consanguineous spouse develops rashes. A kid born to a couple with a similar issue passed away a few days after one week of life. What is the condition?

Epidermolysis bullosa is a rare condition that causes fragile, blistering skin.
The blisters may appear in response to mechanical trauma like minor injury, even from heat, rubbing or scratching.
In severe cases, the blisters may occur inside the body, such as the lining of the mouth or stomach. 
Death is inevitable in severe forms

questions.text: Identify the one which is not useful in the management of GBS:
questions.solution:
Steroids are not useful in the management of GBS.
 
  • Evidences suggest that corticosteroids given alone do not significantly hasten recovery from GBS or affect the longterm outcome.
 
  • Either high-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis (PLEX) can be initiated, as they are equally effective for typical GBS.
 
  • Meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials indicates that treatment reduces the need for mechanical ventilation by nearly half (from 27 to 14% with PLEX) and increases the likelihood of full recovery at 1 year (from 55 to 68%).

questions.text: The most accurate test to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
• Most specific test for carpel tunnel syndrome is Durkan test.

  • Phalen test involves holding the wrist in a flexed position for 60 seconds, while the Tourniquet test involves inflating a blood pressure cuff around the upper arm and leaving it in place for several minutes to increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
  • The Cozen test is a test for lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) and is not used for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: In which of the following situation is  biopsy not indicated in TB spine:
questions.solution:
Biopsy is indicated in TB spine in all except cold abscess without neurological compromise.
In cases of cold abscesses, particularly those caused by tuberculosis (TB) a biopsy may not be necessary if there are no neurological complications and the diagnosis is clear based on clinical presentation and imaging. 
  • Cold abscesses, especially when associated with TB, often have a characteristic clinical and radiological presentation.
  • If a cold abscess is strongly suspected based on factors like tuberculin skin testing, imaging  and patient history, a biopsy may not add significant diagnostic value.
  • Risk of Spread: TB cold abscesses are generally caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and performing a biopsy can increase the risk of spreading the infection either locally or systemically.
  • Response to Empirical Treatment: In many cases of TB-related cold abscesses, physicians might start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) based on clinical suspicion, and the abscess may resolve with medical management. If the patient responds well to ATT, there may be no need for a biopsy.
  • Lack of Neurological Complications: If there are no neurological complications, such as compression of nerves or the spinal cord, the urgency for invasive diagnostic procedures like biopsies is reduced. Neurological involvement might warrant further investigation to prevent long-term damage, but in its absence, conservative management is often preferred.
 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 185
https://atm.amegroups.org/article/view/103385/html

questions.text: All of the following are used to combat COVID19, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
All of the following are measures are used against COVID-19 except 1% glutaraldehyde.

  • sneezing,
  • wheezing,
  • burning eyes, and conjunctivitis.

Therefore, workers may be harmed from exposure to glutaraldehyde.

Glutaraldehyde is used as an disinfectant of endoscopes.

questions.text: What should not be given to a patient with NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Streptokinase.
 
  • NSTEMI (Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction) is a type of heart attack with partial blockage of a coronary artery,but the blockage does not cause the ST segment of the ECG to rise.
  • Treatment for NSTEMI includes aspirin, clopidogrel, and prasugrel. These medications help to prevent blood clots from forming and blocking the coronary arteries
  • Streptokinase, a thrombolytic medication used to dissolve existing blood clots, should not be given to a patient with NSTEMI as it can increase the risk of bleeding and thrombus may embolise to distant small vessels and can cause blockage.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2048-2051.

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the effects of vitamin k by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Competitive inhibition
 
  • Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitive inhibition.
  • Dicoumarol and warfarin competitively inhibit the gamma-carboxylation system due to structural similarity with vitamin K.
  • Therefore, they can act as anticoagulants used for therapeutic purposes.
Dicumarol is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase; thus, it inhibits vitamin K recycling and causes depletion of active vitamin K in blood.

*Mechanism of action:

Dicumarol inhibits the enzyme vit K epoxide reductase (VKOR) and interfere with regeneration of the active hydroquinone form of vit K which acts as a cofactor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase that carries out the final step of γ carboxylating glutamate residues of prothrombin and factors VII, IX and X. This carboxylation is essential for the ability of the clotting factors to bind Ca2+ and to get bound to phospholipid surfaces, necessary for the coagulation sequence to proceed.

* [Extra Edge]: Competitive Inhibitor Vs Non competitive Inhibitor
 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 667.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Rh incompatibility is false?
questions.solution:
Increase in urine bilirubin will be incorrect in Rh incompatibility.

Hyperbilirubinemia occurs due to increase in destruction of RBCs in case of Rh incompatibility. The increased bilirubin is bound with albumin as it is water insoluble and does not appear in urine.

Increased RBC lysis will lead to increased production of bilirubin and will be metabolized to urobilinogen leading to increased urobilinogen in urine and stool.

questions.text: Eukaryotes' intercellular communication is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is mediated by exosome.

Exosomes are secreted by all types of cells and are also found abundantly in the body fluids such as: saliva, blood, urine and breast milk. The major role of exosomes is to carry the information by delivering various effectors or signalling molecules between specific cells covering a very long distance.

questions.text: Methylation of DNA has nothing to do with:

DNA Methylation plays a very important role in a number of key processes including

questions.text: Which is the component that does NOT belong to Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution:
Eosin B is NOT a component of Papanicolaou stain

Staining steps:

  1. Hematoxylin: Applied first to stain the nuclei.
  2. Orange G (OG-6): Applied next to stain keratinized cells.
  3. Eosin azure (EA): Applied to stain the cytoplasm and various cell components, giving differential colors to different cell types.

Light green SF is a sub-component of EA

Purpose of each component:

  • Hematoxylin: Provides contrast for nuclear features, which is critical for identifying abnormal or malignant cells based on nuclear morphology.
  • OG-6 (Orange G): Highlights keratinized cells, aiding in distinguishing different layers of squamous cells.
  • EA (Eosin Azure): Differentiates various types of epithelial cells based on their cytoplasmic staining properties, allowing for the identification of immature, intermediate, and mature squamous cells.




Reference: Bancroft's Theory and Practice of Histological Techniques, 8th edition, Page no 132.

questions.text: Pregnancy-related increases in ESR is caused by:
questions.solution:
Fibrinogen

questions.text: What causes a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell-mediated

Type IV hypersensitivity is also known as cell-mediated hypersensitivity because it is the result of the interaction of T lymphocytes and the specific antigen to which they have been sensitized.

Other options: -
  • Antibodies mediated is Type II HSN reaction 
  • Immune complex mediated is Type III HSN reaction 

* [Extra Edge]: Mechanisms of T cell mediated cytotoxicity
 
  • Cytokine-mediated inflammation: CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 effector cells. Subsequent exposure to the antigen results in the secretion of cytokines. IFN-γ activates macrophages to produce substances that cause tissue damage and promote fibrosis, and IL-17 and other cytokines recruit leukocytes, thus promoting inflammation. The classical T cell–mediated inflammatory reaction is DTH.
  • T cell–mediated cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) specific for an antigen recognize cells expressing the target antigen and kill these cells. CD8+ T cells also secrete IFN-γ.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: Define Hayflick limit:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Total number of times a cell can divide in their lifetime

Hayflick limit is total number of times a cell can divide in their lifetime.
Abolition of telomerase activity results in telomere shortening, a process that eventually destabilizes the ends of chromosomes, leading to genomic instability and cell growth arrest or death.
Therefore, telomere shortening leads to the attainment of the Hayflick limit.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3734.

questions.text: Apoptosome component with cytochrome C and APAF 1 is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Procaspase 9

Components of apoptosome with cytochrome C and APAF 1 is procaspase 9.
In the intrinsic pathway, caspase activation requires the formation of an activating complex called an apoptosome.
This complex is made up of four components, including
  • cytochrome c
  • apoptosis-activating factor 1 (Apaf-1)
  • adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and
  • procaspase-9
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are multipotent primitive cells that can develop into all types of blood cells, including myeloid-lineage and lymphoid-lineage cells. They have trans-differentiation potential and can also regenerate damaged tissue. But their division is strictly regulated by growth factors.

questions.text: Correct way to estimate viral load is:

questions.text: A nurse prescribes an eye drop and an eye ointment to a patient. What should she suggest about applying it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option C) - Eye drops applied first, wait for 15 mins and then apply ointment.

Ointments are greasy semisolid preparations meant for external application to the skin, eye, nasal mucosa, ear or anal canal.

The drug is incorporated in an oily base, such as soft or hard paraffin, wool fat, bee’s wax, etc. Ointments are not suitable for oozing surfaces, because they are more occlusive and do not allow evaporation of water.

Thus, Eye drops must be instilled before applying eye ointment, since the ointment will affect the absorption of the eye drop.

questions.text: A 55-year-old guy had LASIK surgery to correct his myopia. What is the most effective way to test power?

questions.text: What changes in the image can be seen as the objective lens' numerical aperture is increased?

questions.text: A narrow pupil that doesn't change in the dark is present in the condition of:

questions.text: A patient presented with head tilt to the left. On straightening, it leads to right hypotropia. On dextroversion and right head tilt, his right hypotropia seems to worsen. Paralysis of which among the following muscles is likely to be involved in this condition?

questions.text: What statement concerning the corneal epithelium is not true?
questions.solution:
False statement about corneal epithelium is Option 1: Bowman’s membrane can regenerate
 
  • Bowman’s layer is the second layer of cornea situated deeper to the anterior epithelium. It is an acellular layer and does not regenerate following an injury.
  • Therefore, injury to bowman’s layer leads to corneal opacity.
Other options: 
 
  • Option 2: Epithelial stem cells—undifferentiated pluripotent cells that serve as an important source of new corneal epithelium—have been localized to the limbal basal epithelium
  • Option 3: Cornea is lined by nonkeratinized, nonsecretory, stratified squamous epithelium, which is four- to six-cell-layers thick (40–50 µm).
  • Option 4: Extensive apical microvilli and microplicae characterize the cell membranes of the superficial cells.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 155, 156, 158.

questions.text: What is excluded from RBSK is:
questions.solution:
RBSK does not include congenital glaucoma.

And congenital glaucoma is not included in these health conditions.

questions.text: A patient arrived with acute nausea and vomiting and uterine enlargement 12-14 weeks after 10 weeks of amenorrhea. There is an appearance of a snowstorm on ultrasonography. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
The management is suctioning and evacuation.

The given features of snowstorm appearance and increased uterine size along with nausea and vomiting are suggestive of recurrent molar pregnancy.

A molar pregnancy must be removed from the body or it can cause serious complications. Suctioning and evacuation are used for the management irrespective of the uterine size. 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 236.

questions.text: A woman who has experienced amenorrhea for six weeks has slight abdominal pain and bleeding PV, and the pregnancy test result is positive. No gestational sac or free fluid is visible on an abdominal ultrasound. What will the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
Next step in management will be follow up with HCG.

The given features are suggestive of 2 possibilities and they are
  • Missed abortion
  • Delayed implantation

Conservative approach must be chosen and review must be done after 1 week

Follow up need to be done by measuring HCG levels:
  • Decreased levels of HCG are suggestive of aborted pregnancy
  • If the HCG levels are Increased USG needs to be done after 7 days to check for gestational sac.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 222.

questions.text: Identify the one that does not belong to ovulation induction agent in PCOD:
questions.solution:
All the following are options for ovulation induction except ulipristal.

Because ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) and it inhibits or postpones ovulation.

Instead, in case of unprotected intercourse, the administration of ulipristal at or within 24 hours of ovulation has a contraceptive action. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 316.

questions.text: What criteria is used to diagnose an abdominal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Studdiford's Criteria is used to diagnose Primary Abdominal Pregnancy.

Abdominal pregnancy
• Criteria for diagnosis - Studdiford's Criteria
   1. Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy
   2. No evidence of uteroplacental fistula
   3. The presence of a pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary
       implantation after primary tubal abortion

Rubins criteria- Cervical Pregnancy
Spielberg's criteria - Ovarian pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not an oral contraceptive pill's mode of operation?
questions.solution:
Ocps decrease the gonadotropin secretion.


Mode of action
• oestrogen inhibits secretion of FSH via negative feedback on the anterior pituitary, and thus suppresses development of the ovarian follicle
• progestogen inhibits secretion of LH and thus prevents ovulation; it also makes the cervical mucus less suitable for the passage of sperm
• oestrogen and progestogen act in concert to alter the endometrium in such a way as to discourage implantation.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with high blood pressure presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and foetal movement loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Abruption. A pregnant woman with high BP, abdominal pain and abrupt fetal loss can be due to Placental abruption.
 
  • Separation of the placenta—either partially or totally—from its implantation site before delivery is called placental abruption or abruptio placentae.
  • The signs and symptoms of placental abruption can vary considerably. Classically, affected women have a sudden onset of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.
  • High BP is usually the predisposing factor for abruption of placenta. 
  • Bleeding typically insinuates itself between the membranes and uterine wall, ultimately escaping through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.
  • Placental abruption can also be associated with fetal compromise.

questions.text: A 16-year-old child with refractory seizures has several ring enhancing lesions on an MRI of the brain, and MRS results show high lactate, choline, and alanine levels. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Neurocysticercosis.
Causative agent- Pork tapeworm- Taenia solium. 
Most common site-Subarachnoid space along cerebral convexity whereas 

Most common intraventricular site-Fourth ventricle. 

Four different stages have been described using Escobar’s staging:
  • Vesicular stage-
    • Indicates acute infection with live quiescent parasite.
    • Seen as an eccentric dot within the cyst which is called target sign/cyst with a dot sign/dot in a hole sign. 
    • Absence of surrounding edema, inflammation, or post contrast enhancement. 
  • Colloidal vesicular stage- 
    • Early subacute stage. 
    • Due to parasitic degeneration, there is diffusion of parasitic antigens into the adjacent brain which leads to severe inflammation with edema and contrast enhancement- ring enhancing lesion as shown in the given image.  
  • Granular nodular stage-  
    • Late subacute stage 
    • Characterized by body’s attempt to curb the infection. 
    • Decreasing trend of edema, inflammation and contrast enhancement with retraction of cyst wall. 
  • Nodular calcified stage- 
    • Chronic stage of infection with dead, densely calcified parasite.
    • Absence of edema, inflammation and post contrast enhancement. 

The given clinical case along with MRI and MRS findings are suggestive of Neurocysticercosis.
 
Neurocysticercosis is caused due to infection by pork tapeworm, Taenia solium, in the central nervous system.
 
The condition clinically presents as seizures in young adults along with headache, altered mental status. Seizures are the most common presenting symptom.
 
  • It shows multiple ring enhancing lesions on MRI which can also be seen in other conditions such as tuberculomas, metastasis, abscesses. Along with the MRI findings, elevated levels of choline, alanine, succinate and lactate and decreased levels of N- acetylaspartate and creatine are seen on Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy in case of Neurocysticercosis. Thus, the diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis can be made.


Tuberculoma- ring enhancing lesion 

Toxoplasmosis- Multiple ring enhancing lesion with surrounding vasogenic edema 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1791, 1792.

choices.text: Bone marrow affected at higher doses than neurovascular involvement

questions.text: Correct statement about radiation sickness is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Bone marrow is affected first at lower doses than GI tract

Radiation damage is directly proportional to the mitosis and inversely proportional to differentiation of a tissue. 



Acute Radiation syndrome is characterized by 4 stages namely- Prodromal phase, latent phase, manifest illness and recovery/death. 
 
  • Hematological system:
    • First system to get involved due to maximum proportion of undifferentiated cells. These cells are highly sensitive to effects of radiation.
    • Threshold dose is 1-2 Gray.
    • The primary cause of death-infection/hemorrhage
    • Death occurs within few months after exposure.
 
  • Gastrointestinal system-
    • Second organ system to get affected.
    • Threshold dose is 6-10 Gray.
    • Characterized by malaise, severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
    • Death occurs within 2 weeks and survival is less likely.
 
  • Cardiovascular/CNS-
    • Last system to get involved
    •  Threshold dose of ~ 20 Gray.
    •  Death occurs due to collapse of circulatory system and raised intracranial tension secondary to edema, vasculitis and meningitis.
    • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure.
Bone marrow manifestations are seen at dose of 1-2 Gy whereas gastrointestinal tract symptoms are seen at much higher doses of 6-10 Gy, making option 3 the correct statement. 



Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts and Clinical Practice, 9th edition, Page no 1807.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male chronic smoker with a chest radiograph that is Normal and negative for Acid Fast Bacilli has a history of recurrent moderate hemoptysis. Which of the following provides the patient with the highest diagnostic yield?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: CECT chest. 
 
  • The patient in the given clinical scenario is mostly likely having bronchogenic carcinoma. The investigation of choice for evaluation and diagnosis of bronchogenic cancer is CECT. 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of superior sulcus/Pancoast tumor.
  • Bronchoscopy is indicated after CT scan is suggestive of bronchogenic carcinoma in order to obtain a tissue diagnosis. 
The case of a 60 year old male who is a chronic smoker with a history of recurrent hemoptysis suggests a lung tumor.

Since the chest radiograph is normal, the lesion must be small. In order to investigate the lung tumour, contrast enhanced CT Scan is the best investigation. For all lung cancers, CECT is the best investigation except for Pancoast tumour where we do an MRI. Since the question does not give any specific history related to Pancoast tumour, we will go for CECT.

Gold standard investigation is bronchoscopic biopsy. 



Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 597, 598.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the RBC of a G6PD patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency, the correct description of the red blood cells (RBCs) is 4. Hemolyses in hypotonic saline.

G6PD deficiency leads to reduced production of NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of the red blood cell membrane. As a result, these RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative stress and can undergo hemolysis more readily, especially in hypotonic saline. This means they would swell and burst in a dilute solution due to their compromised membrane stability.

The other options do not accurately describe the RBCs in G6PD deficiency:

  • 1. Mutated spectrin: This is more characteristic of conditions like hereditary spherocytosis.
  • 2. Spherical in shape: G6PD-deficient RBCs can be more prone to shape changes due to oxidative stress, but they are not specifically described as spherical.
  • 3. Resist hemolysis in saline: G6PD-deficient RBCs are actually more likely to hemolyze under oxidative stress conditions, including in hypotonic solutions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 640.

questions.text: What is not the initial ventilator setting for a patient with chest trauma:
questions.solution:
In a patient with chest trauma, the initial setting during mechanical ventilation does not include a tidal volume of 10-15 ml/kg.
 
Initially, during mechanical ventilation we use the following settings:
 
The inspiratory flow is around 60-80 liters per min.
The FiO2 is initially kept at 100% which is then gradually decreased as per the requirement in order to prevent any damages
The positive end expiratory pressure is kept 0-5 cm of H2O which would be increased later. This is done because in a patient with chest trauma, keeping a positive end expiratory pressure initially could affect ventricular filling and can cause hypotension.
We always start with a low tidal volume of 4-6 ml/kg since keeping a high tidal volume can lead to alveolar injury caused by continuous stretching and re stretching of the alveoli.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 308.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about treating snake bites is untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Neostigmine and Atropine may be given for krait bite.

Neostigmine and atropine are only effective in cobra bites (neurotoxic poisons)

Families of poisonous snakes.
  • Elapidae (king cobra, common cobra, common krait): Neurotoxic 
  • Viperidae (Russel viper, Saw Scaled viper, Humped pit viper): Hemotoxic 
  • Hydrophinae (Sea snakes): Myotoxic 
Management of snakebite is as follows 
  • First aid: Carry No RIGHT
    • Carry- do not allow victim to walk
    • No- No tourniquet, No sucking, No electrotherapy, No incison, No pressure immobilisation
    • R- Reassurance (Most bites are by non-venomous snakes)
    • I- Immobilise the patient
    • GH- Get to Hospital immediately
    • T- tell doctor about any specific symptom noticed during shifting to hospital
*pressure immobilization is for elapid bite when patient id >1 hour from medical care
  • ASV given if signs of poisoning seen (effective against 4 snakes – Common cobra, krait, saw scaled viper, Russel viper)
  • IV Neostigmine and Atropine given for neuroparalysis.
  • Wound debridement
  • Dialysis
  • FFP
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 563.

questions.text: When a patient dies from a spurious medicine, the following minimum punishment is applied:

Spurious drug is a drug which is sold, exhibited for sale or given to a person under a name which belongs to some other drug or if it is substituted by another drug. Since this caused homicide and is caused intentionally, the minimum punishment is life imprisonment.

  • The fracture shown in the image is a linear fracture since a thin line of fracture can be seen without any depression of the bone.
  • In a depressed fracture the skull bone is depressed at the site of the fracture.
  • In a comminuted fracture multiple fracture lines are seen radiating from a single point. It is caused due to multiple blows.
  • In diastatic or sutural fracture, the fracture line is along the skull sutures.
  • Ring fracture is seen in the base of the skull which can be caused due to falling from a height.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: The depicted image shows the injury:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Incised wound
 
  • The wound shown in the given image is an incised wound since clean cut, sharp, well defined margins are seen and trailing phenomenon can be seen at one end where the wound becomes shallow as we move towards one end.
  • Incised wounds are caused by weapons with sharp edges and the largest dimension in case of incised wounds is the length of the wound which can be seen in this case.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 192.

questions.text: The injury shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. incised looking lacerated wound

The given image shows an incised looking lacerated wound.
 
Since this wound is caused on the scalp (a bony prominence), the margins appear to be similar to an incised wound but it can be identified as a lacerated wound since it is present on a bony prominence which is common for a lacerated wound, also bruising of margins can be seen and on further examination, blood vessels, nerves and hair bulbs would be seen crushed at the base of the wound.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 191.
