questions.text: A habitual alcoholic abruptly stops drinking and is taken to the emergency room in a delirious semiconscious state. How will you handle the situation?
questions.solution:
The symptoms shown by the patient are of alcohol withdrawal.
 
It is treated using oral benzodiazepines and thiamine. Thiamine is given in order to prevent serious complications such as Wernicke's Encephalopathy.
Chlordiazepoxide is usually given as a prophylactic when the patient has a history of seizures. This the best choice when the patient presents with seizures is i.v. Lorazepam + Thiamine.

BZDs safe in Liver dysfunction Memorizing Trick: - LOve The liver 
L- Lorazepam
O- Oxazepam
T- Temezepam

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 580.

questions.text: A patient was planned for a surgical procedure and due consent was taken. However during surgery - the surgeon feels the need to remove more tissue to save the life of patient than what was taken consent for. Doctor can proceed and will not be liable under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option 4. Doctrine of extended consent

The surgeon can proceed without liability under the Doctrine of extended consent if they are required to remove more tissue to save the patient's life. It allows the surgeon to act beyond the initial consent if it is necessary to save the patient's life or prevent serious harm. Extended consent acknowledges that the patient has consented to the procedure in general terms, and the doctor can proceed with additional necessary steps that go beyond the specific details of the original consent.

Other options
  • M'naghten rule: This rule is related to criminal law and the insanity defense, not relevant to medical consent
  • Res Ipsa Loquitor: This is a legal doctrine that allows an inference of negligence in certain cases where the harm caused is so obvious that it speaks for itself (eg. leaving scissors inside abdomen during surgery). It doesn't apply in the context of consent in medical procedures.
  • Doctrine of conjugated consent: This term isn't commonly used in medical legal contexts and doesn't directly relate to the issue of extending consent during surgery.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 49.

questions.text: Even with careful precautions, the ureter is harmed intraoperatively when performing a hysterectomy after receiving informed permission for uterine fibroids. According to which principle is Dr. not accountable?
questions.solution:
The doctor is not responsible for the events under the doctrine of Medical mal-occurrence.
 
Since the doctor took diligent measures and even after that harm was caused to the patient, the doctor is not responsible under the Doctrine of Medical mal-occurrence which states that every person has a different response to different drugs and procedures and even after the most diligent efforts, harm may occur but the doctor is not responsible for these outcomes.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 49.

questions.text: Identify the conjugated antibody in the following figure:
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the antibody numbered 1 is the conjugate antibody.
 
The figure shows a molecular investigation technique which is used for the detection of the antibody marked 2. Since the antibody 1, is attached to the primary antibody (marked 2), it is known as the secondary or conjugated antibody with which a conjugated enzyme is attached. This conjugated enzyme is used to form an end product which can be easily detected. In this manner, the levels of Antibody 2 are measured indirectly.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: The instrument depicted in the image is:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Perkins self-retaining retractor.
  • It can be differentiated from other retractors by the presence of a flat plate on one blade and three prongs of equal size on the other blade.
  • Other retractors such as Mollison's retractor or Jansen Retractor have prongs on both the blades while the Joules self retractor contains circular blades.
  • The flat plate in Perkins' self-retaining retractor is used to retract the skin of the external auditory canal during mastoid and middle ear surgeries.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1149.

questions.text: In a real-world instance, Epley's maneuvre was used to identify and treat vertigo that occurred for a brief period of time and was related to head posture. What is the diagnostic test for the aforementioned condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of vertigo lasting for a few seconds which is associated with position is suggestive of Benign Paroxysmal positional vertigo.
 
This condition is treated using Epley's manoeuvre and is diagnosed using the Dix Hallpike manoeuvre.
In the Dix Hallpike Manoeuvre, the examiner stands at the patient's head and 45 degrees to the right to make the body's sagittal plane align with the right posterior semicircular canal.
 
The patient's eyes are open and he is moved from the seated to the supine position with the right ear down. The patient's neck is then slightly extended so that the chin points slightly upward. If nystagmus is present, we note its latency, duration, and direction. If vertigo is present, note its latency and duration.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 44

questions.text: The cell depicted in the image is:
questions.solution:
The air cell shown in the given image is the anteriormost cell of the ethmoidal sinus which is the Agger Nasi.
 
Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest ethmoidal air cell. Fovea ethmoidalis is a bony plate which separates the anterior ethmoidal sinus from the anterior cranial fossa and forms the roof of the ethmoid sinus. Concha bullosa refers to the condition where the turbinate gets filled with air and enlarges.


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 151

questions.text: The structure shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a tracheo esophageal voice prosthesis.
 
This is surgically implanted in patients who have undergone laryngectomies in order to enable speech production. The prosthesis allows passage of air between the trachea and the oesophagus which enables voice production.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 353

questions.text: An illustration of an injection near the medial canthus is shown. What steps are involved?
questions.solution:
The given image shows anterior ethmoidal nerve blockage procedure.
 
It can be done to prevent postoperative agitation which is a common complication of Ear, Nose and Throat surgeries. The procedure can also be carried during the treatment of nasal fractures.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 154

questions.text: Within 4-6 hours, a child starts dribbling saliva, has swallowing difficulties, and appears with a high-grade fever and inspiratory stridor. Which of the following needs to be administered in addition to airway management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IV ceftriaxone
 
  • The symptoms described, including dribbling saliva, swallowing difficulties, high-grade fever, and inspiratory stridor, are consistent with acute epiglottitis.
  • Epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. The most common causative organism is Haemophilus influenzae type B.
  • Airway management is a priority in these cases, and IV ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice to cover the likely pathogen.
  • Antibiotics like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone are used to treat HIB infection.



Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 1107.

choices.text: immediately as soon as the last dose given

questions.text: Lithium therapy is continued for a patient with bipolar illness. When will you as a doctor ask the nurse to have the serum lithium levels checked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 12 hours after the last dose
 
  • Lithium's effectiveness is dose-dependent and consistently correlated with serum lithium levels (trough levels).
  • The optimum time to measure trough levels is right before the next dose. Lithium is given in two divided doses in clinical practice, trough levels are assessed 12 hours following the last dosage.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: The condition in the liver according to the given image is caused by:
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Symmers Pipe-Stem Fibrosis or Bilharzial Clay Pipe Stem Fibrosis which is a form of periportal hepatic fibrosis caused by Schistosoma Mansoni infection.
 
In the image we see a longitudinal section showing large areas of fibrosis around the vessels and bile ducts.
The fibrosis is the result of granulomatous inflammation in the portal tracts caused by Schistosoma Mansoni eggs.

 S. japonicum: Leads to Katayama fever, liver fibrosis, liver cirrhosis, liver portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and ascites. 

S. haematobium schistosomiasis : includes hematuria, scarring, calcification, squamous cell carcinoma, and occasional embolic egg granulomas in brain or spinal cord.

 Clonorchis : C sinensis can live for years within the biliary system of humans and result in various symptoms, including cholecystitis, cholangitis, and cholangiocarcinoma. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 148.
